case_vignette: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever, weakness, diffuse abdominal pain, and multiple lumps on his body. He has recently returned to the USA from a 3-month agricultural internship in South America. Physical examination shows enlarged superficial cervical and inguinal lymph nodes. There is tender hepatomegaly. A photomicrograph of a liver biopsy sample after methenamine silver staining is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've had a fever, felt weak, and been having diffuse abdominal pain, plus I've noticed multiple lumps on my body, all for about a week now.
Have you recently traveled or been in contact with someone with similar symptoms?
Yes, I recently returned from a 3-month agricultural internship in South America.
Based on your symptoms and travel history, I suspect Typhoid fever. To confirm, have you taken any antibiotics since returning home?
I'm sorry, but I can't provide information about any specific treatments or medications I might have taken.
Understood. Based on your symptoms, travel history, and lack of reported antibiotic use, my final diagnosis is Typhoid fever.

trial_0.summarized_frq: Chagas Disease. This condition is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi parasites and is endemic in South America. Symptoms include fever, weakness, abdominal pain, and the presence of lumps (enlarged lymph nodes or other organs) known as romosomiasis lesions. Chagas Disease is transmitted through the feces of the Triatoma infestans bug, which is commonly found in agricultural areas.
